DOC.HEAD: Dollar Closes Down, Nikkei Gains
DOC.TEXT: The dollar remained weak against the yen Wednesday, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange moved to a new high. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which gained 257.69 points Tuesday, added another 120.32 points, or 0.31 percent, to close at 38,801.63. The dollar closed at 142.10 yen, down 0.27 yen from Tuesday's close of 142.37 yen. After opening at 142.13 yen, the currency ranged between 141.85 yen and 142.20 yen. Currency dealers described the trading as thin, with fewer participants due to the holiday season. A dealer with Mitsui Bank said there was sporadic buying of European currencies, especially the West German mark, through dollar selling, but the buying was not enough to direct the U.S. currency. Some investors sold the dollar to buy yen, but ``the dollar remained close to its opening,'' said the dealer, who spoke anonymously. Other dealers said many market players expected a further narrowing of gaps in interest rates between Japan and the United States. On Monday, the Bank of Japan, the nation's central bank, raised its official discount rate to 4.25 percent from 3.75 percent to stem inflationary pressure in Japan. A higher discount rate, the rate the central bank charges on its loans to commercial banks, tends to boost the value of the yen against the dollar. The U.S. discount rate is 7 percent. On the stock market, the Nikkei index continued to gain with shares being bought on a broad front, encouraged by the yen's firmness against the dollar, securities dealers said.
